I had my eye on this game since I purchased the Rift, but since it was always so pricey, I waited for a sale.  It finally became cheaper, and decided to get it, and I have to say after beating it it is absolutely overpriced.  It essentially combines the climbing and combat of Tomb Raider with the stealth and survival themes of The Last of Us, but doesn't approach the quality of either of the titles from which it draws inspiration.  

While the art style is good, the graphics are clearly aimed at the minimum Rift specs, and there is no option to improve them beyond that.  The gameplay involves balancing combat with distraction based stealth - you basically throw rocks to make enemies move away from your intended route.  You will be doing this a lot, and despite my love of stealth, the repetetiveness of the mechanics get old pretty fast.  There are some Tomb Raider-esque climing elements thrown in where you navigate linear tracks that often disintegrate as you traverse them, and this aspect also grows tiresome.  This game feels like it has a tiny handful of gameplay ideas that get repeated over and over again.  

That leaves the story, which is a is clearly inspired by Lovecraft, and was probably the main reason I kept playing.  However, ultimately the payoff just wasn't there, and I felt a bit disappointed at the conclusion.  There are a few in-your-face jump scares during chapter interludes, which will either attract or repell players depending on their tastes.  

If you are looking for a good third person action survival game, this 'aint it, though if you are a horror fan, you may enjoy it more than others.  Edge of Nowhere is a short, predictable adventure with decent art style and a few jump scares thrown in that is neither memorable nor a great representation of the strengths of VR.  At the very least it is a competent third person action-horror game, but I would still only recommend it to fans of the genre - and even then only if its on a very generous sale.

review_title: A quality and fun experience but . . .
one_reviews_text:
There is basically zero replayability, so you'll go through the game probably one time only and never play it again. And the game only lasts a handful of hours too, which makes is hard to recommend unless you have the cash to spare.

The addition of some branching paths, some hidden areas and secrets to find, and maybe even some bonus modes and stuff for completing sections in fast times or something like that would have been very much welcome.

If, however, you're fine with spending the money on a one-play experience then I'd actually recommend it; it's actually one of the more polished and engaging VR games I've played. But if you want to get good value for your money, and have VR experiences that you will return to time and time again and ultimately get many, many hours of fun from, even if the main campaign only happens to be a handful of hours long, then I woulnd't recomment this game.

But don't get me wrong: It's polished, intersting/engaging, and fun--if you think of it like an expensive extended playable movie experience or something like that.

review_title: Like a snowfield - beautiful but bland
one_reviews_text:
I like 3rd person adventure games. The Uncharted series and the Tomb Raider reboots are among my favourites, and while I wasn't expecting Edge of Nowhere to live up to those, some nods in their general direction would have been nice.

EoN is utterly linear - there is literally nothing off the beaten path to discover at all. As you take those initial steps forward, it doesn't take long to realise that this is all you'll do, as you're constantly funnelled down a "corridor" for the entire game. Some areas might be slightly wider than others, but make no mistake, there's no hidden routes or caves, and every collectable is placed firmly in your path, as if the developers feared  you might miss a scrap of story.

There aren't any puzzles to break up the forward plod either - nothing to tax your mind or creativity. Wall after wall needs to be climbed, but after the first hour you realise they're simply there to slow down your pace and extend the game.

Inventory is simply shotgun shells and rocks, and you'll curse the fact that despite lugging a backpack around, you're limited to a ridiculously small amount purely due to gameplay reasons, and that it was the only way to add a challenge to the game. The problem is that in a lot of places, just one or two extra shots from your gun would wipe out the challenge of an entire area, and each area rapidly becomes the same. You're in a cave - get through the cave without dying, climb a wall out of the cave, and repeat. There is the odd area (especially with a certain giant beasty) that breaks up that monotony, along with the odd hallucination, but it's mostly the same.

VR saves this game in as much as it can. If this had been released as a desktop game, there would have been questions being asked as to what went wrong.

review_title: One of the best experiences in VR
one_reviews_text: Its actually one of the best stories I experienced in VR so far. With twists, psychological elements that make use of VR and small details. (look at the dead bodies of humanoid mutants when they are behind you). Its a very well crafted lovecraftian story, with a lot of tropes and references that you might recongnize, without getting dull. Arstistically its a beautiful game - the landscapes and design of the lovecraftian monsters is top notch. Graphically its ok -the polygon count is sometimes kinda low by todays standards and textures are to bland - VR limitations I guess, but could be way better. Gameplaywise its nothing revolutionary - basicly each level is a big tunnel with some climbing, stealth, fighting or a chase. But the story and presenation makes you forget the basic gameplay very fast. It might get very scary btw, so consider that - the monster ai is suprisignly fun and you can experiment with it for a bit.  I finished the game in 6h feels like a perfect length for this game. In the end it was one hell of a ride.

While the use of VR here is great at giving you the sense of scale, I'm still not a fan of the detachment you get when using your VR headset to aim and direct the camera. The reason being is that, you can often lose track of your character when trying to examine your suroundings or aim your gun. Would like to see some use of the right analog stick (which has no function in this game at all) for at least a little camera movement, for example it could control turning your character in a 3d environment and you can still use the tracking of the headset to aim/look around in the frame. This isnt too bad for a game that has a very linear progression path, but it still seems like developers are still struggling with how to best implement the game camera for 3rd person games.  The game is well voice acted and is one of the best looking VR games i've played despite spending alot of time in the dark. Its certainly very atmospheric. The gameplay is fun enough but its really basic stealth gameplay. you make distractions with rocks, some stealth takedowns, and when you get enough ammo u can really go loud and unload on the buggers.  Its fun enough but theres not alot to it. All in all i still feel like we're in the experimental phase for VR third person games, and this is an example of a solid experiance in that regard, but ultimately, i feel like we're knocking on the door of greatness here without steping through the threshold

It's only maybe 4 hours long, without much replay value other than higher difficulties, but worth it for anyone who wants to know how a AAA console-style game translates to VR.

This is the perfect sit-down VR action game that feels natural to play with the XBox controller, and it isn't a driving or flying simulation. The experience was like both being inside a movie and watching the movie at the same time. The blending of game play and story telling was among the best. The plot had enough twists and turns with great pacing and never felt dragged out. The use of the VR third person and the occasional first person always felt natural without inducing motion sickness. At the climatic end of the game, it was satisfying to be finally reunited with the person my character had spent so much effort searching for, even if in the back of my mind I knew what was coming next. It left me both in awe and in horror as the nightmare inevitably came true and the credits started to roll.

review_title: This is a FUN game - you will enjoy it.
one_reviews_text: 3rd person games in VR - seems strange but it works.  It actually works much better then expected.  (Nintendo - I want a VR 3rd person Zelda......)  This game reminded me of Uncharted.  Much of the game play is well thought out and VR really adds Scale and perspective to the game.  When you see a giant monster in YOUR FACE it is scary!  No feeling of dizzyness or other typical VR issues just a fun time playing.  I took one star off for the last few levels of the game - I feel like they padded the final few levels to make the game longer and the game seemed to drag a bit near the end.  Still a super awesome game!  If you love Uncharted or other 3rd person action games this game is for you.
